Authors: Philip Stevenson Ward, Michael G Branstetter
Title:
The acacia-ants revisited: phylogeny and biogeography of an
iconic ant-plant mutualism
Journal: Proceedings of the Royal Society B
Abstract:
Neotropical acacia-ants in the Pseudomyrmex ferrugineus
group and their associated Vachellia (formerly Acacia) hostplants are a
textbook example of a closely integrated ant-plant mutualism. The ants
receive shelter and food from the hostplant, and in return they
aggressively defend the plant against herbivores and competing plants.
Considerable attention has focused on the ecology and behavior of these
ants, but the evolutionary history of the group has received less
scrutiny. Using ultraconserved element (UCE) sequence capture and
comprehensive taxon sampling, we analyze phylogeny, biogeography, and
trait evolution in the ferrugineus group. Results confirm the existence
of two separate lineages of obligate acacia-ants that convergently
evolved protective behavior, from timid ancestors inhabiting dead twigs
in rainforest. The older and more diverse of the two clades (eight
extant species) is inferred to have arisen in the late Miocene in
northern Mesoamerica, and subsequently expanded its range throughout
much of Mexico and Central America. The other lineage (two species) is
estimated to have originated in southern Mesoamerica about 2.5 Mya,
apparently piggy-backing on an existing mutualism. The initiation of the
Pseudomyrmex/Vachellia mutualism was associated with a shift in the ants
from closed to open habitats, likely an environment with more intense
plant herbivory.
